document.docTitle: The effect of β-cyclocitral treatment on the carotenoid content of transgenic Marsh grapefruit (Citrus paradisi Macf.) suspension-cultured cells

paragraph.docTitle: The effect of β- cyclocitral treatment on the carotenoid content of transgenic Marsh grapefruit ( Citrus paradisi Macf.) suspension-cultured cells

document.paragraph:
Xiongjie Zheng a, 1
, Kaijie Zhu
a, 1
, Junli Ye
a
, Elliott J. Price
b, c, d , Xiuxin Deng
a, **
, Paul D. Fraser b, *

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Key Laboratory of Horticultural Plant Biology (Ministry of Education), Huazhong Agricultural University, Wuhan, China

paragraph.emphasis: School of Biological Sciences , Royal Holloway , University of London , Egham Hill , Egham , Surrey , TW20 0EX, UK
Faculty of Sports Studies, Masaryk University, Brno, Czech Republic
RECETOX Centre, Masaryk University, Brno, Czech Republic

subSection.paragraph: Citrus
Suspension-cultured cells Chemical elicitor β- yclocitral
Carotenoid
Provitamin A
ABSTRACT

This work reports the development of suspension culture system of transgenic Marsh grapefruit ( Citrus paradisi Macf., Rutaceae ) callus overexpressing bacterial phytoene synthase; and the use of this suspension culture to investigate the effects of β- cyclocitral on carotenoid content and composition. At a β- cyclocitral concentration of 0.5 mM and after ten days cultivation, analysis of the carotenoids showed a significant increase in the content of β-, α- carotene, and phytoene predominantly. The maximal increase in total provitamin A carotenoids content following β- cyclocitral application was ~2-fold higher than the control, reaching 245.8 μg/g DW. The trend for increased transcript levels of biosynthetic genes PSY and ZDS correlated with the enhancement of the content of these carotenes following β- cyclocitral treatment and GC-MS based metabolite profiling showed significant changes of metabolite levels across intermediary metabolism. These findings suggest that β- cyclocitral can act as a chemical elicitor, to enhance the formation of carotenes in citrus suspension-cultured cells (SCC), which could be utilized in studying the regulation of carotenoid biosynthesis and biotechnological application to the renewable production of nutritional carotenoids.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 1. Carotenoid biosynthesis pathway and the precursors for β- cyclocitral synthesis in plants. GGPP, geranylgeranyl diphosphate; PSY, phytoene synthase; PDS, phytoene desaturase; Z-ISO, ζ- carotene isomerase; ZDS, ζ- carotene desaturase; CRTISO, carotenoid isomerase; LCYe, lycopene ε- cyclase; LCYb, lycopene β- cyclase; BCH, carotene β- hydroxylase; CYP97C, cytochrome P450-type monooxygenase 97C (carotene ε- hydroxylase); ZEP, zeaxanthin epoxidase; VDE, violaxanthin de-epoxidase.

emphasis.heading: 2.1. Effect of β- cyclocitral treatment on the carotenoids content and
composition of citrus suspension-cultured cells

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. Effect of twelve days treatment with different concentrations of β- cyclocitral on the carotenoid content and composition of transgenic citrus suspensioncultured cells. (A) Carotenoids content and composition of citrus SCC. The letters represent significantly different groups following ANOVA. (B) HPLC-PDA chromatograms of carotenoids and colour change of citrus SCC following 0.5 mM β- cc treatment. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

Fig. 3. Effect of twelve days treatment with different concentrations of β- cyclocitral on growth index of citrus suspension-cultured cells. The letters represent significantly different groups following ANOVA.

subSection.paragraph: Once it was known which β- cc concentration induced the maximal levels of provitamin A carotenoids, the time course of provitamin A carotenoids production was analyzed in citrus SCC elicited with 0.5 mM β- cc. As shown in Fig. 4 , the content of all carotenoids, expect phytoene, was decreased from day 0 to 4th day. However, significantly increased accumulation of total and provitamin A carotenoids was observed by day 10. In contrast, the content of xanthophylls (violaxanthin and lutein) was always lower under β- cc treatment than control.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 4. The effect of β- cc (0.5 mM) treatment on the carotenoid content and composition of transgenic citrus suspension-cultured cells at different growth stages. Error bars represent standard deviation (SD) of three biological replications.

emphasis.heading: 2.2. The effect of β- cyclocitral on the expression of genes involved in
carotenoid formation and degradation in citrus suspension-cultured cells

subSection.paragraph: Transcriptional regulation of carotenoid biosynthetic genes is a major molecular mechanism for carotenoid accumulation in plant ( Enfissi et al., 2017 ; Nogueira et al., 2013 ). As such, carotenoid pathway gene expression was profiled at 4th, 7th and 10th day of 0.5 mM β- cc treatment. As shown in Fig. 5 , at four days post treatment only CitZDS was significantly altered by β- cc treatment being up-regulated, in comparison to control. At 7th day, the expression of genes upstream of α/β- carotene biosynthesis ( CitDXS , CitPSY and CitZDS ) alongside the downstream gene CitZEP, was increased in SCC under β- cc treatment. At 10th day, expression of CitGGPPS and CitBCH was significantly increased, in addition to all genes that exhibited significant upregulation at 7th day. The trend for increased expression of key carotenoid biosynthetic genes correlated with the enhancement of carotene contents in SCC observed at 7th and 10th day under β- cc treatment.

heading.emphasis: 2.3. Changes in intermediary metabolite pools associated with
β- cyclocitral treatment of citrus transgenic suspension-cultured cells

caption.paragraph: Fig. 6. Changes in metabolite pools of suspension-cultured cells resulting from fourteen days β- cyclocitral (0.5 mM) treatment. Asterisk indicate significance of difference at *P value < 0.05, **P < 0.01 and ***P < 0.001, respectively. Red coloured asterisks indicate the relative metabolite contents increased by β- cc treatment whilst green represent a decrease. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

Fig. 5. The effect of β- cyclocitral treatment on the expression of carotenoid biosynthetic and catabolic related genes in transgenic citrus suspensioncultured cells. The concentration of β- cc used in this experiment is 0.5 mM.

subSection.paragraph:
β- cc has been demonstrated to be a stress signal which modulates photosynthesis and root growth ( Dickinson et al., 2019 ; Ramel et al., 2012 ) whilst β- ionone (another β- carotene derived volatile apocarotenoid) treatment did not elicit similar response to excess light stress in
Arabidopsis ( Ramel et al., 2012 )
. In addition, our result showed that the same concentration of β- ionone cannot mimic β- cc effect on content of carotenoids in citrus SCC ( Fig. S2 ), suggesting that β- cc plays a specific role on both induction of stress signal in
Arabidopsis
and modulation of carotenoid formation in citrus SCC. Moreover, β- cc treatment increased expression of upstream carotenoid biosynthetic genes DXS , PSY and ZDS gene after seven days ( Fig. 5 ), which is consistent with the enhancement of carotenoids content. Thus, one can speculate a possible mechanism is that high concentration of β- cc mediated stress signal plays a feedback role in the transcriptional regulation of carotenoid biosynthesis, thereby increased carotenoids content in citrus SCC. Among the carotenoids, α- carotene, β- carotene, cis -β- carotene, phytoene and phytofluene were increased in citrus SCC by β- cc application. In contrast, the xanthophylls, lutein and violaxanthin, showed a slight reduction following β- cc treatment ( Figs. 2 and 4 ). Thus, β- cc shows a specific positive effect on production yield of all carotenes. Alongside the provitamin A carotenoids the colorless carotenes, phytoene and phytofluene are themselves valuable bioactive widely used in many skin care products due to their antioxidant properties and harboring several purported beneficial effects on human health ( Miras-Moreno et al., 2019 ). Previous studies in non-green tissues have demonstrated that pushing metabolic flux to carotenoids by gene manipulation results in a more predominant accumulation of β- carotene, phytoene and phytofluene than xanthophylls ( Cao et al., 2012 ), likely due to the lower carotenoid hydroxylase activity than in green tissues. It is plausible that in the citrus SCC β- cc may act directly on the hydroxylase enzymes as an inhibitor. Limiting the pathway at this step could create multiple feedback/forward loops in an attempt to bring homeostasis to the pathway. For example, the absence of end product xanthophyll could stimulate the earlier steps in the pathway to increase flux through the pathway and thus expression of these early pathway genes arises ( Fig. 5 ). Expression levels of genes subsequent to cyclization and involved in xanthophyll formation were increased concurrently in an attempt to overcome the inhibition at the enzyme level.

To further understand how β- cc affects carotenoid concentrations in a holistic manner across metabolism, metabolite pools associated with intermediary metabolism were analyzed. Previous studies have demonstrated the interconnectivity of primary and secondary metabolism. For example, the steady state level of many diverse metabolites in transgenic tomato fruit was shown to be significantly perturbed ( Enfissi et al., 2010 , 2019 ). The β- cc treatment in the transgenic SCC had broad effects across the metabolome ( Fig. 6 ). An increase in sugars, amino acids, and organic acids suggests that the β- cc lead to increase the carbon source in cell cultures. The decreases of overall triterpenes following β- cc treatment support increased flux of precursor isoprenoids towards carotenoid biosynthesis. However, the most prominent metabolic perturbation was the increase in signaling compounds GABA and dopamine, indicating that the modulatory effects of β- cc were far reaching across metabolism.

In the present study, we report that β- cc treatment can be applied to enhance the contents of provitamin A carotenoids, phytoene and phytofluene in carotenoid-biofortified transgenic citrus SCC. These changes in carotenes contents were accompanied by increases in the expression of genes upstream of α/β- carotene biosynthesis and altered intermediary metabolite contents. These results highlight that the chemical elicitation strategy has a great potential to be utilized in improving valuable carotenoids production in plant cell factory. Furthermore, the suspension culture of carotenoid-biofortified transgenic citrus callus has a potential as a fundamental tool for the study of carotenoid regulation and small molecule/elicitor modulation of the pathway.

heading.emphasis: 5.1. Plant materials and plant cell culture conditions

subSection.paragraph:
The establishment of transgenic Marsh grapefruit ( Citrus paradisi Macf., Rutaceae ) callus lines overexpressing the
Erwinia uredovora Crt B
gene have been reported earlier ( Cao et al., 2012 ). The stable transgenic line was sub-cultured into fresh solid medium every 2 weeks as previously described ( Cao et al., 2012 ; Zheng et al., 2019 ). To establish suspension cultures, friable calli grown on solid medium were transferred into a Murashige and Skoog (MS) liquid medium (containing vitamin B5) supplemented with sucrose ( 50 g /L), 4-morpholineethanesulfonic acid (MES, 0.5 g /L), Vitamin C ( 0.5 g /L), malt extract ( 0.5 g /L) and L-glutamine ( 1.5 g /L). The pH of the suspension medium was 5.85. Sixty mL of suspension-cultured cells were cultivated in sterile flasks (200 mL) placed on a horizontal orbital shaker set to 120 rpm, and at a temperature of 25
◦
C under darkness. The callus cells were sub-cultured into fresh suspension medium every two weeks.

Suspension-cultured cells were pre-cultivated in liquid media for 4 days prior to β- cyclocitral (β- cc) treatments. These suspension cells were cultured in 60 mL media containing 0 mM (control), 0.1 mM, 0.5 mM or 1 mM β- cc and harvested at 12 days after β- cc treatment. In addition, the suspension cells with 0.5 mM β- cc treatment were harvested at 0 days, 4th day, 7th day, 10th day and 14th day. Growth index (GI) of suspension-cultured cells under different treatment conditions was defined as GI = (final fresh weight of biomass - initial fresh weight of biomass)/initial fresh weight of biomass ( Arano-Varela et al., 2020 ).

All the data are presented as the mean ± SE (standard deviation of the mean) of three biological replications unless stated otherwise. The statistical analysis of data was carried out using the Microsoft Excel program. One-way ANOVA and Student’ s t-tests were used to calculate significant difference of expression level of carotenoid pathway genes in suspension-cultured cells between treatment and control. Multiple comparisons of carotenoid content were performed by using SAS version 8 (SAS Institute, Cary, NC). The Heml 1.0 software was used for heatmap displaying of the metabolites data from GC-MS analysis.
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

This work was supported in part through the National Key Research and Development Program of China (2018YFD1000200), European Union Framework Program DISCO (from DISCOvery to products: a nextgeneration pipeline for the sustainable generation of high-value plant products; Project 613513), the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council OPTICAR Project (optimisation of tomato fruit carotenoid content for nutritional improvement and industrial exploitation), National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 31930095, 31630065) and a China council scholarship. We greatly appreciate Hongbo Cao, Kit Liew, Rapacz Elzbieta, Chris Gerrish and Karl Crosby for their excellent technical assistance.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2020.112509.
